briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 12, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Extreme Weather Events Striking the World and Their Impacts
sections.content: As of 2026, climate change is no longer a theoretical risk but a present reality [34]. Deadly floods in Indonesia are a complex result of climate change and deforestation [39], and in the UK, flood victims are appealing for help amidst fears of the next disaster [52]. In the United States, in addition to changes in daily life such as basement flooding, analyses have also emerged indicating that climate change has already negatively impacted Americans' incomes [37, 41]. Domestically, the direct impacts of extreme weather are evident, with a 'caution' fire risk alert issued nationwide due to heavy snowfall, cold waves, and strong winds [3, 4]. The Cortina d'Ampezzo region in Italy has declared a state of emergency due to climate change and is responding by producing artificial snow [1].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± South Korea's Steps Towards Renewable Energy Transition and Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: South Korea has been designated as the chair country for the upcoming International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) General Assembly, seizing a significant opportunity to lead global discussions on renewable energy [17, 19, 20, 25, 27, 30, 31]. Domestically, POSCO Steelion is accelerating towards carbon neutrality goals by constructing solar power facilities [11]. Educational institutions like Jeju National University and Ulsan National University are also contributing to strengthening carbon neutrality capabilities through fostering environmental engineering talent and operating greenhouse gas academies [12, 13]. Carbon neutrality efforts are continuing across various sectors, including Pohang City's expanded distribution of household food waste disposers [14], Jeonbuk Self-Governing Province's target of achieving 91.1% renewable energy self-sufficiency by 2030 [23], and the government's promotion of turning livestock manure into renewable energy [29]. Furthermore, HMM is actively introducing wind-assisted propulsion systems, leading the eco-friendly transition in the shipping sector [33].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Challenges in Achieving Renewable Energy Targets: Infrastructure and Policy Limitations
sections.content: Considering the low efficiency of fossil fuels, the transition to renewable energy is essential [15]. However, the target of achieving 100GW of renewable energy by 2030 is accompanied by significant infrastructure issues. Specifically, substation problems in the Honam and Jeju regions are delaying the achievement of this goal [24], and we face a 'paradoxical' situation of expanding renewable energy without expanding the transmission grid [26]. Experts point out the limitations of renewable energy facilities, emphasizing the need to find alternative solutions within regional power systems [28], and suggest that a transition to a 'region-led power market' is urgent to achieve 100GW of renewable energy by 2030 [21].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Policy Controversies and Psychological Barriers
sections.content: Policy controversies surrounding climate change response continue in the international community. The United States' move to withdraw from the UN Climate Change Convention has been criticized by some experts as potentially illegal [36, 51], which could negatively impact global climate cooperation. Simultaneously, research has been published indicating that 'psychological biases' risk slowing climate change progress [38], and anxieties about having children amidst the climate crisis also exist [35]. Furthermore, the U.S. plan for oil development in Venezuela has raised concerns about potentially depleting 13% of the world's remaining carbon budget for the 1.5Â°C target by 2050 [50], demonstrating the severe impact of energy policies on climate goals. Amidst these circumstances, scientific efforts to uncover clues about climate change through marine sediment research are ongoing [43].

briefing.closing: As we have reviewed in today's briefing, climate change is profoundly impacting our lives and societies worldwide in various forms. Efforts to transition to renewable energy must continue, but a thorough review and urgent development of solutions for the infrastructure and policy limitations arising during this process are critical. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: Like the 'Age of Discovery': HMM Hoists Sails Again, Traversing the Five Oceans
articles.original_title: â€˜ëŒ€í•­í•´ì‹œëŒ€â€™ì²˜ëŸ¼â€¦HMM, ë‹¤ì‹œ ë› ë‹¬ê³  ì˜¤ëŒ€ì–‘ ëˆ„ë¹ˆë‹¤
articles.description: HMM Introduces HD Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering's 'Wing Sail' Wind Propulsion Device, Expecting 5-20% Fuel Savings. HMM's 50,000-ton medium-sized oil tanker 'Oriental Aquamarine' has been equipped with HD Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering's wind-assisted propulsion system (WAPS). HMM announced on the 12th that it has officially commenced the adoption of this technology, developed by HD Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering, raising the prospect of ships once again navigating the seas primarily by wind power.

summary.phenomenon: On the 12th, HMM officially commenced the introduction of the 'Wing Sail' wind-assisted propulsion system (WAPS), developed by HD Korea Shipbuilding & Offshore Engineering, by installing it on its 50,000-ton medium-sized oil tanker, the 'Oriental Aquamarine'.
summary.cause: The 'Wing Sail' is a wind-assisted propulsion system that utilizes wind power to propel vessels.
summary.outlook: Fuel savings of 5-20% are anticipated with the introduction of this device.

articles.original_title: US plan to exploit Venezuelaâ€™s oil could eat up 13% of carbon budget to keep 1.5C limit
articles.description: Exclusive: ClimatePartner analysis shows how move would risk plunging Earth further into climate catastropheUS plans to exploit Venezuelaâ€™s oil reserves could by 2050 consume more than a tenth of the worldâ€™s remaining carbon budget to limit global heating to 1.5C, according to an exclusive analysis.The calculation highlights how any moves to further exploit the South American nationâ€™s oil reserves â€“ the largest in the world, at least on paper â€“ would put increasing pressure on climate goals, and

summary.phenomenon: According to ClimatePartner analysis, U.S. plans to develop Venezuelan oil could consume more than 10% (potentially 13%) of the world's remaining carbon budget by 2050, which is necessary to limit global warming to 1.5Â°C.
summary.cause: U.S. plans to develop Venezuela's oil reserves, the largest in the world, are expected to cause significant carbon emissions.
summary.outlook: Further development of Venezuela's oil reserves risks increasing pressure on climate goals, plunging the Earth deeper into climate catastrophe, and making it difficult to achieve the 1.5Â°C warming limit target.

articles.description: Presidentâ€™s memo stating US â€˜shall withdrawâ€™ from UNFCCC marks first time any country has tried to exit the agreementThe Trump administrationâ€™s long-anticipated decision this week to pull the US from the worldâ€™s most important climate treaty may have been illegal, some experts say.â€œIn my legal opinion, he does not have the authority,â€ Harold Hongju Koh, former head lawyer for the US state department, told the Guardian. articles.description: As climate breakdown puts millions more people at flood risk, traumatised homeowners are finding common voiceDarren Ridley is always on high alert, constantly checking his phone for rain warnings â€“ even in the middle of the night.â€œOur whole family is permanently on edge,â€ he says. â€œIf we hear rain, day or night, weâ€™re up and checking the house. I canâ€™t sleep without replaying our flood plan in my head for weaknesses.â€ Continue reading...

summary.phenomenon: In the UK, residents affected by floods are living in constant fear of the next deluge, continuously checking for rain warnings and uniting to seek assistance.
summary.cause: Climate breakdown is identified as the cause, placing millions more people at risk of flooding.
summary.outlook: Climate breakdown is expected to put more people at flood risk, and traumatized homeowners are likely to continue demanding assistance and raising their voices.
